Name: Toystore Chess
Description: Toystore Chess begins with an empty 5x5 board and a King, Queen, Rook, Bishop, and Knight in reserve for each player. Opponents alternate placing one piece at a time on any open square until all pieces are on the board. Play proceeds as Chess.

Name: State Capitals
Description:
Players will be able to correctly match the 50 states in the USA with their capitals.

Object of play is to form matched pairs of states and their capitals. When a player gets rid of all of his or her cards, that player wins the game.

Scoring: The winning player receives 5 points for each card remaining in the other players' hands, whether they form matched pairs or not. Each player, including the winner, receives 10 points for each correctly matched pair and loses 10 points for each incorrectly matched pair that he or she laid down during the game. A list of states and their capitals should be provided to assist players during scoring.

Components:
100 cards
50 states & 50 capitals

Name: States in Mind: Regional Rummy & State Line
Description:
The players(s) shall be able to recognize the various regions within the United States and group states accordingly.

Player in his turn asks any one participant for a card from a particular region. If the participant has a card from that region, that card is given to player. If not, player draws a card from the stock pile. If card drawn from stock pile is of the region requested, player may continue to call on individual participants for a specific region until players or pile do not respond with region requested.
Play continues to left. When player has a complete region, that region is placed in a stack on the table.
Game is won by player with no cards remaining in hand.

Components:
50 cards

Name: Hunt and Seek Through History
Description:
Find the greatest number of objects hidden in the game boards. In the “Time Challenge”, children are invited to locate eight objects used to measure time in each of the eras depicted on the game boards.

Bilingual (french / english). This game of observation develops a child’s visual acuity and concentration while providing an opportunity to learn a second language. Beautifully illustrated game boards allow children to explore prehistory, ancient Egypt, Grecian antiquity, the Middle Ages, the Far West, the pirate era, the discovery of America and, finally, a glimpse of the future.

Object of the game:
To locate illustrations in the game boards and collect as many cards as possible

Box contains:
4 game boards double sided
50 cards
Game rules

Name: Street Drug Rummy
Description:
Street Drug Rummy is intended to familiarize players with the common names and major classifications of illegal and abused drugs which are all too readily available on the streets today.

The object of the game is to group the cards with General Classification, Specific Drug Families, Way Administered or Sudden Death. Players can challenge another player on classifications, families, or sudden death combinations. The drug chart (last page) is used to judge the validity of the challenge.

Components:
54 cards

Name: Strike-a-Chord
Description:
The players will be able to organize keyboard musical-note representations into appropriate chord formations and state the name of the chord sequence correctly.

If the player has three or four cards forming a chord, the chord sequence is placed on the table. The player must then tell the other players the name of the chord. If correct, this player's turn continues by selecting another card as in step 2. If the player is incorrect, another player may "steal" the chord by stating the chord name correctly.
The winner is the player with the most chord formations.

Components:
46 cards

Name: Striking a Balance
Description:
Players will be able to analyze physical quantities into their fundamental units of measurement.

The object of Striking a Balance is to form balanced equations of physical units that appear in many physics formulas. Equations are formed with cards in various combinations, each card bearing a physical quantity which is broken down into its fundamental units. The winner of a round is the first person to "go out" as in Rummy, which means that the player can use all the cards in his/her hand to form complete equations. Points may be accumulated at the end of each round and the grand wazoo is the player who reaches 100 points first.

Components:
48 cards

Name: Suave Poker
Description:
The players will be able to identify the personal pronoun and verb tense of irregular Spanish verbs. This edition of the game includes only the present, imperfect, preterite, future and conditional tenses.

Gameplay is similar to poker. Combinations are with Spanish persons, tenses and verbs.

Components:
For twenty irregular verbs, there are a possible 500 cards.

Name: Subtraction Sentences
Description:
The players will be able to correctly complete subtraction sentences.

The object of the game is to be the first player to get rid of all of his/her cards. To do this, the players must use their cards to make subtraction sentences.
Player places in his turn either a number card, a minus card, an equals card, or a wild card with the face up card to create a subtraction sentence. A wild card can stand for any card the player wants.

Components:
75 cards

Name: Synonyms
Description:
The players will be able to increase their vocabulary.

The object of the game is to form sets of two or three cards which are synonyms. 
The first player to go out (have no more cards in his hand) wins. If a time limit is set instead, the winner is the player with the most cards on the table at the end of the predetermined time period.

Components:
250 cards

Name: The Game of Hickory, Dickory, Dock
Description:
Information from gamearchives.org:

Each player selects a piece and begins the game either on the "Start Here" space or the "Or Here" space. Players take turns spinning the indicator and moving up as many places as the indicator shows. Players play in turn trying to reach the UPPER SPACE first. A player must reach the UPPER SPACE by exact count in order to win. "When the clock strikes 1" that is to say, when a player spins a 1, instead of moving forward  one space his piece is immediately dropped to one of the spaces marked "Start Here" and the players piece is obliged to climb again. The only time a 1 does not cause a piece to return to the start space is if the piece is 1 spot away from winning and a 1 would be required to win the game. Then the 1 spin does indeed win the game.

Name: Game of Robinson Crusoe
Description:
From Gamearchive.org.

The popular story of "Robinson Crusoe" forms the basis for this game for children. In the pack of cards, with which  the game is played are several cards which have exact duplicates, but there is only one card each for Robinson Crusoe, Friday and Rescue Ship. The cards are dealt out one at a time and if the player has two cards that are the same kind, that is 2 Goats, Turtles,  Cannibals etc. the player pairs them up and they are thrown out of the game. Then the start player begins by drawing randomly from the player to his left 1 card. If he pairs a card the pair is removed, Then the next player draws a card. Play continues this way until one player successfully gets the 3 cards CRUSOE,FRIDAY, and RESCUE in his hand whereby winning the game.

Name: The Prisoner of Zenda
Description: In this game there is a board on which are illustrated the castle at Zenda and the palace at Streslau and numerous playing tracks representing the roads between them. There are 3 dice, 4 large pieces and 8 small green pieces who are soldiers. The large red piece represents the king who was the Prizoner of Zenda, 2 large yellow pieces represent Rudolph and Colonel Sapt and the large Green piece represents Black Michael. To win the Zenda player has to capture green pieces with his yellow pieces to open a hole in the green line through which his red piece may slip to Streslau and thus win the game. The Streslau player should try and stop all paths leading to his city by blockade at critical points.

Name: Monkey Shines
Description: The game centers on a 3-D tree with a plastic trunk and cardboard leaves. Each player gets 3 monkeys in their color (there are 12 monkeys total plus one black chimpanzee figure). Players roll dice to have their monkeys climb the tree via holes in the trunk. If a double is thrown, the player must place the chimpanzee figure a number of holes. Any monkeys the chimpanzee passes must return to the bottom of the tree and start over. The first player to get three monkeys to the top of the tree wins.

Name: Heroscape Expansion Set D1: Champions of the Forgotten Realms
Description:
Champions of the Forgotten Realms is the eleventh Small Expansion Set (wave 11) in the HeroScape series.  It is the first expansion (wave D1) for the Dungeon and Dragons crossover started by Heroscape Master Set:  Battle for the Underdark.  It is also fully compatible with all previously released Heroscape products.

There are 4 booster packs: 

     Heroes of Faerûn
     Warriors of the Ghostlight Fen
     Fury of the Primordials
     Glaun Bog Raiders


Each pack contains 5 figures and a glyph.

Name: BOMP
Description:
BOMP! Reach the center of the ring and Bomp out your opponents, with grace and precision! 
Only one will survive, or maybe two, or maybe all of your three warriors, if you Bomp really well!

Bomp is a fast paced and interactive fingertip game, for 1,2,3,4 players (solo game is possible and useful to train your fingers) up to 8 players with the expansions you can choose with other 4 teams you like.

Realized with big and coloured 25 mm Spielmaterial wooden discs, the game was presented at Ideag 2010.

For any info-order feel free to contact the author
anporaz@libero.it

Name: Animal Hunt
Description: Along the lines of Scrutineyes and / or Where's Waldo.  Search and find different animals on a colorful game board.

Name: Apollo Space Rocket Checkers
Description: A checkers varient with a spinner determining possible moves.  The game board also dictates special or extra possible moves.

Name: Go! The Bahamas Game
Description:
This is a roll and move race game where one player has 3 airplanes and the other one has 3 sailing ships... both players vie to get all 3 of their markers along the track to Nassau first.  Extra turns may be earned and opponent markers may be blocked or sent back to the start.

So basically a nostalgic "tourist souvenir" game where you move pawns around a colorful illustrated game board with the instructions printed right on it.

Name: Fight that Fire Game
Description:
Typical roll and move game on a very boring looking game board that is somewhat hard on the eyes.

Contents include: 32 Playing Cards, 4 Markers, 10 Fire Safety Tips Cards, 10 Chief's Orders & 1 Die.

Name: Guys Next Door
Description:
Game about the short lived Saturday morning TV series.  There was a band called the Guys Next Door (1 album released) and the TV show centered around a series of sketch comedy skits featuring the band.  Basically, it was a failed attempt at capitalizing on the New Kids on the Block mania.

The game is a typical teen girl fantasy game about boys.

Contents include: 20 Personal Color Photos, Set of Dream Girl Fantasy Cards, Dream Girl Spinner, 4 Pawns & Photo Gameboard with BONUS autographed photo of Guys on the back.

Name: Oh Magoo, You've Done it Again
Description:
A roll and move game with colorful 3D board elements.  Instructions are printed on the board.

Contents include: 5 Player Pieces, 17 Playing Cards, 8 Card Buildings and Die.

Name: Queah's game
Description:
A traditional game from Liberia. This game is played by Queah tribe. Game plays on a 5x5 checkered board. Each player has 10 piece in his own color. Game start with an initial start positon with 8 game piece in two different color on board.Pieces moves diagonally as checkers.

On each turn, each player may:
Move one stone to a diagonal adjacent empty cell.
Or, jump (diagonally) over an enemy stone landing on the immediate empty cell. The jumped stone is captured and the other player must place a piece to an empty cell of the board with same color with used cells of board. (if there are in staock). The players only use the squares of the same color).

The aim of this game is capturing all ennemy stones.

Name: Seegover
Description:
This is an attempt to make a game like Seega which is less subject to draws.

This game is played on an empty 5x5 square board. There are 24 double-sided pieces. The game is played in two phases. In the first players alternate placing two pieces at a time with their color showing; any squares may be occupied except the center. In the second phase players alternate moving one piece into the empty square.

A capture is made by sandwiching a single opposing piece between two of one's own. The captured piece is turned over. If at least one capture is made the moving piece may be moved back to the space it came from if that will result in additional captures.

There are two different versions of the game, depending on which rule one uses for the case where a player cannot move because they have no pieces adjacent to the empty space. In version one the player may take any of their pieces and place it in the empty space, but even if they capture they cannot then move it to its original space. In version two the player may turn over a piece adjacent to the empty square; in this case if captures are made the piece may be moved into the empty square if it can make further captures.

In either version the game ends when a player loses by having fewer than five pieces.

The game may also be played by three players using cubes with three colors on them; each player starts with eight of these.

Name: Simultana
Description:
This game is played on a 5x5 board. Game starts with a setup position.
Each player moves one of his stones orthogonally respecting the following restriction:
The moved Black stone must create at least one adjacent area of 3 or 5 empty cells.
The moved White stone must create at least one adjacent area of 2 or 4 empty cells.
The aim of this game is trapping the opponent pieces.
The first player unable to make a move, loses.

The original rules suggest playing on larger boards as well - use 9 pieces per player on a 6x6 board and 14 on a 7x7 board.

Name: Tandems
Description:
This game is played on a 5x5 board. Game starts with an initial setup position. On each turn, each player must move two friendly stones to adjacent (diagonal or orthogonal) empty cells, both in the same direction. Stones cannot move into the restricted points on game board.

The player that first moves 5 stones to the last row wins the game.

Name: Toads and Frogs
Description: This game is played on an empty 1row x n coloumn board with m stones on each side. At each turn, each player must do one of the following actions. Move a stone forward (i.e., left to one player, right to the other) or jump over one enemy stone, landing on the immediate empty cell. The player who makes the last move wins the game.

Name: Vanakriget
Description:
This game is played on a 5x5 square board. Players start to game with a initial setup position. Each player has 7 game piece in his/her own color.
On each turn, each player must do one of the following things:
Capture a stone on a (orthogonal or diagonal) forward direction by jumping over it and landing on the immediate empty cell. Captures are multiple and mandatory.
Drop a captured friendly stone on any empty cell.
Move a stone on a (orthogonal or diagonal) forward direction to an empty cell.
The player that moves his all game pieces to the opponent's setup position wins the game.

Name: Vector Powers
Description:
This game was presented at 100 Strategic Games for Pen and Paper by Walter Joris. The game is played on a 4x4 board. Each player has 4 game piece in his/her own color.
At the begining of the game each player alternately, place eight friendly stones each.
During just four turns, each player shifts one row left/right, one column up/down or one of the two main diagonals, just by one cell. 
Every stone pushed out the board is removed from play.
After those four turns (i.e., eight shifts), The player with more stones on board wins the game (or a draw if equal).

Name: Vilbergen
Description:
This game is played on a 3x4 rectangular board. Each player has 5 pieces in his/her own color.
At the begining of the game each player alternately place a stone into an empty cell exept one restricted cell.
After all cells occupied, On each turn, each player must do one of the following actions:
Capture an adjacent stone on an orthogonal direction by jumping over it and landing on the immediate empty cell. Captures are multiple and mandatory or move a piece on an orthogonal direction to an empty cell.
The player that captures all enemy stones, or has his last stone on the restricted cell wins the game.

Name: Wali
Description:
This is a traditional 2-player game from West Africa, played on a 5x6 rectangular board. Each player has 12 game pieces in her own color, which start off the board; traditionally one player uses small sticks, the other uses pebbles.
Players initially take turns to place ('drop') one of their pieces on the board.  Each must be dropped on an empty space on the board.  One source states that this must not be adjacent (orthogonally) to a friendly piece, but the original descriptions by Monot [1950], translated by Murray [1951] only state that - during this stage - no player may form a row of three of her own pieces.  If a player cannot make a legal drop, she must pass. This continues until all pieces are placed on the board, or until no more pieces can be placed.
After that, in each turn and starting with the player who began the game, each player moves one of their own pieces to an empty adjacent (orthogonal) space on the board. If, by so doing, she is able to make an orthogonal  row of exactly three of her own pieces, she may capture one enemy piece (of her choice, presumably).  The player who captures all of her opponent's pieces wins the game, and scores two points if this is achieved without any of her own being captured, or one point if she has lost at least one of her own pieces.  A series of matches is played, and the series is won by the first player to score 10 points.

Name: Chicken Roundabout
Description:
Chicken Roundabout is a board game inspired by the 'Chicken Roundabout' in in Ditchingham, near Bungay (Suffolk, UK) a roundabout (traffic circle) famous for the chickens which can always be seen there.

The game is basically an enhanced version of Pachisi/Ludo, with the addition of 'tokens' required to get the chickens home. In this version, opponents' chickens can not be sent back to the start by overtaking them.

The game was previously marketed as 'Us Chickens'. The new version differs by having local businesses featured on the spaces on the board.

Name: Twister Moves: Hannah Montana Edition
Description:
From the publisher:
Dance along to Hannah Montana's awesome songs! This cool Twister Moves game allows you to listen to her music and move as the DJ tells you to! Put the CD in your machine, set out the mats and away you go! Listen carefully to the instructions and follow the fun moves! If you're the only one to get the moves right, you win! Practice on your own and then compete against friends! A wonderful way to encourage active play! Great for any Hannah Montana fan!

Name: BrainBox: Manchester United Game
Description:
From the publisher:
Manufacturer's Description
BrainBox Manchester United is a game for the whole family. The game is ingeniously simple. A player has ten seconds to study a card that shows players past and present in action and is then asked a question about the card, chosen by the roll of a die. If the card is answered correctly the card is kept, if not it is returned to the box. The most cards held after ten minutes decides the winner. Cards are real photos of players, with extra information like how many caps the player has, the year of their International debut and what shirt number they wear. Hard core fans can put their knowledge to the test--especially if their powers of observation let them down. The game is presented in a smart cube box and is a perfect gift for Man U fans who already have everything.
Families: Sports Teams: Manchester United Football Club

Name: BrainBox: Math
Description:
From the publisher:
 The object of the game is to win as many cards as possible in ten minutes. The first player takes a card from the BrainBox and turns the timer over. The player then has ten seconds to study the picture on the card. When the timer runs out the card is passed to player two and player one rolls the die to see which question is to be asked. The questions are on the reverse of the picture card. Player two checks the answer by looking at the picture and if it is correct the card is given back to player one to keep. If the answer is wrong the card is placed back into the BrainBox and the next player chooses a card. Please remember, the answer to the question is on the picture side of the card, so look carefully! The player with the most cards after ten minutes wins! If there is a tie, it's sudden death with both players choosing a card and having to answer all eight questions on the card. The player who answers the most correctly wins! For 1 or more players, ages 8+. Contains 54 illustrated cards, 1 rules card, 1 timer and 1 eight sided die. Have fun!

Box Contains

     54 picture/question cards
     1 rules card
     1 sand timer
     1 eight-sided die

Name: BrainBox: Football
Description:
From the publisher:
What can you spot in ten seconds? Turn the timer over and try and memorize as many pictures and words as you can. After ten seconds, pass the card to another player who asks a quick-fire question. Seems easy - cards include the following clubs - Arsenal, Aston Villa, Barnsley, Birmingham City, Blackburn Rovers, Blackpool, Bolton Wanderers, Bradford City, Brentford, Brighton & Hove Albion, Bristol City, Bristol Rovers, Burnley, Cardiff City, Carlisle United, Charlton Athletic, Chelsea, Chesterfield, Colchester United, Coventry City, Crystal Palace, Derby County, Doncaster Rovers, Everton, Fulham, Gillingham, Grimsby Town, Huddersfield Town, Hull City, Ipswich Town, Leeds United, Leicester City, Leyton Orient, Liverpool, Luton Town, Manchester City, Manchester United, Middlesbrough, Millwall, Newcastle United, Northampton Town, Norwich City, Nottingham Forest, Notts County, Oldham Athletic, Peterborough, Plymouth Argyle, Portsmouth, Port Vale, Preston North End, Queens Park Rangers, Reading, Scunthorpe, Sheffield United, Sheffield Wednesday, Southampton, Southend United, Stoke City, Sunderland, Swansea City, Swindon Town, Tottenham Hotspur, Tranmere Rovers, Walsall, Watford, West Bromwich Albion, West Ham United, Wigan Athletic, Wolverhampton Wanderers, Wycombe Wanderers, Yeovil

BrainBox Football Kids GamesPlayers will have 10 seconds to study a card before being asked a question from the back, chosen by the roll of the die. If the question is answered correctly the card is kept, if not it is returned to the box. The player with the most cards after 10 minutes wins the game!BrainBox Football Kids Games is a brilliant memory recall game that lasts just 10 minutes with rounds of ten seconds. Club history, famous players, fun facts and more! Features 71 football clubs from the Premiership, Championship and Leagues 1 and 2.

Name: BrainBox: History
Description:
From the publisher:
What can you spot in ten seconds? Turn the timer over and try and memorise as many pictures and words as you can. After ten seconds, pass the card to another player who asks a quick-fire question.

History How many things can you spot in ten seconds? Turn the timer over and try to memorise as many of the pictures and words appearing on the beautifully-illustrated cards. After ten seconds, turn the card over, roll the die and answer a quick-fire question to win the card. The player with the most cards after 10 minutes wins. A fun way to learn history, from Stonehenge to the Channel Tunnel. Age 8 and above.

Name: BrainBox: Nature
Description:
From the publisher:
The object of the game is to win as many cards as possible in ten minutes. The first player takes a card from the BrainBox and turns the timer over. The player then has ten seconds to study the picture on the card. When the timer runs out the card is passed to player two and player one rolls the die to see which question is to be asked. The questions are on the reverse of the picture card. Player two checks the answer by looking at the picture and if it is correct the card is given back to player one to keep. If the answer is wrong the card is placed back into the BrainBox and the next player chooses a card. Please remember, the answer to the question is on the picture side of the card, so look carefully! The player with the most cards after ten minutes wins! If there is a tie, it's sudden death with both players choosing a card and having to answer all eight questions on the card. The player who answers the most correctly wins! For 1 or more players, ages 8+. Contains 54 illustrated cards, 1 rules card, 1 timer and 1 eight sided die. Have fun!

Box Contains

     54 picture/question cards
     1 rules card
     1 sand timer
     1 eight-sided die

Name: Brainbox: My First ABC
Description:
From the publisher:
The object of the game is to win as many cards as possible in ten minutes. The first player takes a card from the Brainbox and turns the timer over. The player then has ten seconds to study the picture on the card. When the timer runs out the card is passed to player two and player one rolls the die to see which question is to be asked. The questions are on the reverse of the picture card. Player Two checks the answer by looking at the picture and if it is correct the card is given back to Player One to keep. If the answer is wrong the card is placed back into the Brainbox and the next player chooses a card. Please remember, the answer to the question is on the picture side of the card, so look carefully! The player with the most cards after ten minutes wins! If there is a tie, it's sudden death with both players choosing a card and having to answer all eight questions on the card. The player who answers the most correctly wins! For 1 player Look at the card as above for ten seconds. Then turn the card over and answer all the questions (use a pen and paper to record the answers). If all questions are answered correctly the card is kept. If any answers are incorrect, the card has to be put back in the Brainbox. See how many cards you have after five or ten minutes.

Name: BrainBox: Kings & Queens Of England
Description:
From the publisher:
The object of this game is to win as many cards as possible in ten minutes.

The first player takes a card from the BrainBox and turns the timer over. The payer then has ten seconds to study the picture on the card. When the timer runs out the card is passed to player 2 and player one rolls the die to see which question is to be asked. The questions are on the reverse of the picture card. Player 2 checks the answer by looking at the picture and if it is correct the card is given back to player 1 to keep. If the answer is wrong the card is placed back into the BrainBox and the next player chooses a card. The player with the most cards after ten minutes wins. If there is a tie, it's sudden death with both players choosing a card and having to answer all eight questions on the card. The player who answers the most correctly wins.

For 1 or more players, and ages 8+.

Kings and Queens How many things can you spot in ten seconds? Turn the timer over and try to memorise as many of the pictures and words appearing on the beautifully-illustrated cards. After ten seconds, turn the card over, roll the die and answer a quick-fire question to win the card. The player with the most cards after 10 minutes wins. A fun way to learn about our kings and queens of the realm. Age 8 and above.

Name: BrainBox: Art
Description:
Did you know that Vincent van Gogh painted over 900 paintings in his lifetime? And can you name the artist of Britain’s greatest painting? Developed in conjunction with London’s National Gallery, BrainBox Art is full of interesting facts and amazing images of some of the best paintings in the world in stunning high quality on 56 beautifully-illustrated cards.

The object of the game is to study a card for 10 seconds and then answer a question based on the roll of a die. If the question is answered correctly, the card is kept and the person with the most number of cards after 5 or 10 minutes is the winner.

This simple concept can be played by all ages and in large groups as well as a 1 person game. Made from a minimum of 70% recycled material and designed in the UK, the BrainBox range is fabulous fun. Find out who the BrainBox is in your family – it may not be who you think it is!

Players 1 or more,
Ages 8 to 88,
Contains 56 illustrated cards, 1 rules card, 1 timer and 1 eight-sided die,

Name: BrainBox: U.S. Presidents
Description:
From the publisher:
 The object of the game is to win as many cards as possible in ten minutes. The first player takes a card from the BrainBox and turns the timer over. The player then has ten seconds to study the picture on the card. When the timer runs out the card is passed to player two and player one rolls the die to see which question is to be asked. The questions are on the reverse of the picture card. Player two checks the answer by looking at the picture and if it is correct the card is given back to player one to keep. If the answer is wrong the card is placed back into the BrainBox and the next player chooses a card. Please remember, the answer to the question is on the picture side of the card, so look carefully! The player with the most cards after ten minutes wins! If there is a tie, it's sudden death with both players choosing a card and having to answer all eight questions on the card. The player who answers the most correctly wins! For 1 or more players, ages 8+. Contains 54 illustrated cards, 1 rules card, 1 timer and 1 eight sided die. Have fun!

Includes all 44 Presidents from Washigton to Lincoln, JFK to Obama. Can we do this...Yes we can!

Name: Loups gris en Atlantique
Description:
Loups gris en Atlantique (Grey wolves in Atlantic) is a single player game which simulates German patrols of a U-boot during WWII.

The player is a U-boot commander and his mission is to sink a maximum of allies boats during the beginning of 1941.
He has choice between 4 types of submarines (VII, IX.B, IX.C, IX.D2) with their own specificities and he can personnalize his character and crew with points.

Rules are easy and, like many solitaire games, needs a lot of dice rolls.

Name: Wyx
Description:
Wyx is a 2 to 4 player game where each player control an ant queen on a 8 by 8 squares board.
After each move the queen lay an ant egg, althoug on some square she may lay more than one.
The moves are done by chosing from 4 columns of dominos, the top of each column being visble. Each dominos have a vertical and horizontal values indicating the move the queen will have to execute.

The aim of the game is to be the first player to lay out its 16 eggs.

Name: The Easter Bunny Game
Description:
The Easter Bunny Game is a pickup and delivery game in which players of all ages move their bunnies around the board, collecting Easter eggs, and delivering them to homes in time for Easter.

The game is played with chocolate mini-eggs; approximately 24 in four colours are required each game.

If I get the balance right, older kids and adults will enjoy the challenge of planning efficient routes and beating the opponents to the more lucrative destinations, while younger kids will still enjoy scoffing the eggs :)

Ingredients:
12 cards
Board
4 counters
24 miniature chocolate eggs... you'll need a new supply for each game!

Name: Limited Life-Span Theatre
Description:
Notice: I have removed the old rules and files due to there being a completely new version in the works, and the previous versions had too many "bugs".

A game full of less brains and more shooting. Create your character, grab some items, and destroy your buddies. Build your play area however you want, using as many or as few obstacles and pickups as desired!

Gameplay consists of drawing weapon and equipment cards as well as special cards to help break the rules. From Death Matches to trying to be the Last Man Standing, there are several match types to suit different styles of play.

Move around the play area by rolling dice and measuring out the distance. It's like a single man skirmish with you trying to be the winning player as you complete the terms of victory for various match types.

Name: Dino Duel
Description:
Get ready for the battle of the ages when you go head to head in a series of dinosaur duels!

Is your Stegosaurus strong enough to defeat your opponent's Apatosaurus?

Let the fun and the dino duels begin!

The Dino Duel Card Game is one dino-mite game to play! Players lay down their cards in a duel. On the top of the cards is located the point value. If your Stegosaurus card contains more points than your opponent's T-Rex card, then you win that set of cards. The cards feature the Tyrannosaurus Rex, Apatosaurus, Stegosaurus, and wild cards. Any number of combinations can create different outcomes. The player with the most sets wins!

Contains 48 cards (measuring 4 1/2" x 3") and instructions. No reading required to play.

Name: Flick Pool
Description: Flick Pool is a dexterity game distributed in Whataburger kids meals. It consists of round tiles and triangular "pockets". Players take turns flicking the Cue Ball into other balls to try to get them in the pockets. It's just like pool, but smaller and flatter.

Name: Race to Read
Description:
As players roll the die, they make their way around a colorful racetrack. When they land on different colored spaces, players choose cards that ask them to figure out parts of speech, noun plurals, verb tenses, blends, homophones, definitions, idioms, context clues, anagrams and more. As players correctly answer questions, they power ahead on the track. Teachers can choose how many laps to complete to adapt to time constraints. Covers the following aspects of Bloom's Taxonomy: Knowledge, Comprehension, Application, Analysis

*  Compact size saves space on the shelf and in the classroom
    *  High-interest graphics and content
    *  Short passages allow time for full comprehension and the chance to read a variety of topics
    *  Winning is based on knowledge and skills, not random factors
    *  Games address important content, not trivia
    *  Directions are easy to understand, so as not to restrict learning opportunities
    *  Players never lose points for wrong answers

Name: Gauntlet
Description:
Gauntlet - From the Klix Pocket Travel Games from Tiger Electronics.

The board folds out, the magnetic pieces (which function as both player pieces and tokens for the potion track) are stored in a built-in compartment and the dice are self-contained in a see-through compartment. The dice are 'rolled' by pushing and releasing the 'dice snapper'.

The board itself is broken into four sections: "Room 1", "Room 2", "Room 1-3 Treasure Room" and "Room 4". The players take turns moving through the rooms in order, landing on one of four kinds of space: a blank space, a space with food on it (which adds to the players food/HP), a space with a ghost on it (which subtracts from the same), and a space with a bomb (which advances the players 'potion track' by one). The final space on the Room 4 board contains the 'Sacred Orb'.
Families: Series: Klix Pocket Travel Games (Tiger Electronics)

Name: Rakete
Description:
One of the "Easyplay Kids" series. This one is a simple dice-roller.

Each player has a set of five 6-sided dice showing one of five different monsters and a rocket. One monster is revealed at random from a deck of five cards and players simultaneously roll their dice (one at a time). The round ends when one player has four dice matching the monster on the card and the fifth die does not show the rocket.

The losers pay the winner in "Mars Maggot" tokens (to feed the monster). If they can't afford to pay then they must discard a "Rocket" token. The first player to lose all their rocket tokens loses the game; the Player with the most "Mars Maggot´s" win.

Name: Battle with the Swedes for Charles Bridge
Description:
From the rules:  "In the course of the cruel Thirty Years' War, the people inhabiting the Czech Lands were subjected to many invasions by Swedish mercenaries who looted burghers' houses, aristocratic palaces, churches, libraries and monasteries.  Regardless of whether they were led by Generals Baner, Torstenson or Wrangel, the Swedes always wanted to take away as much as they could . . . On the night of July 25, 1648, the Swedish cavalry tried to conquer the Stone Bridge (today's Charles Bridge) and penetrate the Old Town through the gate in the Old Town bridge tower . . .The people of Prague, and particularly students led by Father Jiri Plachy, quickly took up arms and rushed to help the tiny unit of the tower guards.  A fierce hand-to-hand fight ensued, with the fighters on both sides hiding behind the the statues on the bridge.  The battle took the toll of many dead and wounded on both sides.  The present game is based on this particular battle with all its snares and personal fights."

The rules are in Czech, English, German and French.  The board is a simple checkerboard-type surface on medium-weight cardboard.  The only other components are 28 small wooden blocks, 14 dyed red, 14 in their natural light brown coloring. There is a coin on the front of the box that is tossed at the start of the game to determine how many moves the Swedish player gets.

Each player places their 14 men on the first two rows of squares on each side of the board. The men can move one square in 12 possible directions.  You eliminate your opponent's men by landing on their square and can take another turn provided you can eliminate another man with that move.  All men can jump over each other.  The player who has more of his men on the starting line of his rival when no one can make any more moves wins.

Name: Zooloretto: Iberian Lynx
Description:
A special expansion tile available at LeiriaCon 2010 exclusive of Spiel Portugal and later re-released at Spiel 2013 in Essen

The first player to fill his 6 spaces enclosure gets the lynx tile and puts it next to his barn. The players keep the Lynx until the end of the game.

At the end of the game, after the last truck is chosen and before the scoring phase, the owner of the Lynx may carry out one extra money action. He still has to pay the cost for this action.

Expands:

    Zooloretto


Home Page & Newsletter:

     www.zooloretto.com 


(German, english, dutch, hungarian, spanish, swedish)

Name: Diceopolis
Description: This is a strategic placement game wherein each of 2 to 4 players begins with 25 regular 6-sided dice. In the center of the playing surface is a cross of dice ("the wall" - see diagram) against which dice are placed to score. Each die placed must touch two other dice, and only dice touching the same number in the wall in an uninterrupted perpendicular alignment will score. (Two players may begin with 36 dice each if available.)

Name: Cheese Merchandiser
Description:
Every player gets 20 cards in his/her color. Try to get a product together with four cards.
The objective of the game is to put the products on the board as favorable as possible. The player who puts his product on the middle of the board gets the most points.
The player throw two dice and put his/her two pawns on the grid of the board. Where the two pawns come together, a player can put a card of his/her product.
If there is already a card, a player can change the card (only if he/she is the owner of the product). Or can try to get the space for his own product.(players throw dice to get the space)
When a player has placed all his/her products on the board, the counting begins. The player with the most points wins the game.

Name: Après Ski Het Spel
Description:
There are 80 cards with questions at the front of the card. At the back of the cards there are collered lines (the ski arenas). The group or player who gets the longest line, wins the game.

The question are truth or style. If a player answers a question correctly or follows the instructions , he/she gets the card. Otherwise the card is put back in the box.

Contents:
- 80 cards
- 1 CD (just for fun)

Name: Le Franc Tireur #12: PTO and Chinese Civil War for ASL
Description:
80 color pages, articles mainly analyze beach landings in both the ETO and PTO. Includes map LFT 2 (very large hill), two ASL solo scenarios, and 10 ASL scenarios, focusing on the Pacific Theater and the Chinese Civil War, almost all in English.

Scenarios:

     SASL FT-1 Hit Them Hard: You play Nationalist Chinese forces trained by the Germans involved in a counter-attack in Shanghai, 15 August 1937.
     SASL FT-2 Against Ill Advice: You play Japanese army troops sent ahead in Malaya to defend a beach against British counterattacks.
     ASL FT 136 Shanghai by Sea: Nationalist Chinese versus Japanese Shanghai Expeditionary Force making a beach assault in Wusong (south of Shanghai), 23 August 1937.
     ASL FT 137 300:  Last stand in Shanghai of the Nationalist Chinese 88th Division (German-trained) against the Japanese Shanghai Expeditionary Force, 30 October 1937.
     ASL FT 138 Meeting Up at Matan:  Nationalist Chinese against Japan's Formosa Infantry Brigade west of Wuhan, 24 June 1938.
     ASL FT 139 Ride of the 200th:  Japanese Infantry versus Nationalist Chinese armor in Kunlun Pass in south China, 19 December 1939.
     ASL FT 140 Chinese Raiders:  Nationalist Chinese irregular forces fighting in Vietnam against Vichy French helped by Meos partisan forces, 1-2 June 1942.
     ASL FT 141 Easy Day at Volupai:  Japanese infantry versus U.S. marines in New Britain, 6 March 1944.
     ASL FT 142 Cut, Slash and Mow Down: U.S. infantry defend against elements of the crack Japanese 6th infantry on Bougainville, 24 March 1944.
     ASL FT 143 Red Scare:  Fighting between Nationalist and Communist Chinese forces in North China, 13 November 1948.
     ASL FT 144 Tigers of Pantang: Fighting between Nationalist and Communist Chinese in North China, 16 November 1948.
     ASL FT 145 Bears of Kinmen: Nationalist infantry defend against Communist Chinese beach assaults on Kinmen Island, just off the coast of Fukien province, 25 October 1949.


Magazine Contents:

     Editor's Foreword
     Hexdraw, a voyage into "Kibbling"
     Kill the Monsters!
     Very very few products [sic] reviews
     10 question to... Klas Malmstrom
     Tournaments and Meetings
     Japanese Island Defenses
     The Chinese Infantry Battalion
     Iloilo Museum
     Chronology: the Japanese/Chinese war
     Chronology: the Chinese Civil war
     Play fast?
     Sims Ridge AAR
     PTO Basis
     Sons of Beaches
     Seaborne Assaults
     Gavutu-Tanambogo
     Bibliography
     Sims Ridge scenario custom map

Name: Turn of Mind: A Game of Psychological Type
Description:
The player will be able to identify the four elements of a psychological type and state the type represented by the phrases on the cards. The learner will be able to distinguish characteristics of the pairs of opposites represented by the phrases on each card.

The goal of the game is to form a hand comprised of one psychological type and three characteristics of one of the four areas of preference. The three characteristics must be the opposite of the one used to form the type.

Components:
52 cards

Name: Vertebrate Classification
Description:
The players will be able to correctly classify contemporary and extinct chordates according to physical characteristics.

Players try to create the classification hierarchy. Players must correctly identify which Genus belongs to which Order, and which Orders belong to which Class. This can be done from memory, or by reading the Genus characteristics on the cards and matching with them with correct Order characteristics.

As players obtain cards they will be able to place them in the play area if a higher card has already been placed in the play area. (for example a Genus card can only be placed in the play area if and only if it's Order card is available.)
The game is won when a complete hierarchy is built.

Components:
126 cards
- 21 Order cards
- 35 Class cards
- 70 Genus cards

Name: Visual A "peel"
Description:
The players will be able to choose the two dimensional shapes.

The object of the game is to collect the sides needed to create the surfaces of the shapes on the green cards. For example, if you were collecting the sides of a cube you would collect and group six square side cards. You can collect the sides of more than one shape at a time if you choose! 
The game ends when a player plays all of her cards and wins or the time for the game runs out. If time runs out, add up the points on the cards in your hand. Subtract ten points for every stack of sides you successfully played in front of you during the game. The player with the LEAST number of points wins!

Components:
134 cards
- 8 green 3-d shape cards.
- 96 blue 2-d surface or side shape cards
- 30 flat red flexible building blocks

Name: Wildflower Rummy
Description:
To help learn Latin names, Genus/species, and descriptions of common wildflowers found in San Diego County.

Gameplay is similar to rummy.

Components:
50 cards

Name: Womb to Tomb
Description:
The players will be able to identify factors, traits, and lifestyles which contribute to life longevity or early death. They will be able to state whether the trait or lifestyle has a negative or positive effect on life span.

The object of the game is to get two different types of cards for each of the seven suits. When this occurs the player calls rummy. A player cannot call rummy if the cards are duplicates or make contridictory statements within the suit. For example "A nondrinker card and a heavy drinker card"

Each player starts arbitarily with 70 years. Score is computed once someone rummies. When rummy occurs, the person getting rummy receives 15 extra years of life. Each player totals their plus and minus years and adjusts their life span. Play may only be one round dealt(highest score wins), or can be accumulative over several hands. First one to 120 years(current actual record) is the winner, or when someone runs out of years the highest person wins.

Components:
108 cards

Name: Women's History Game
Description:
The player will be able to match famous women in American History with their historical importance (politics, labor, author, social work, or special interest).

Each of the other three players are given decks of equal fact cards. Players choose between blue, green or yellow. As the dealer lays down a face card, the players must lay down the appropriate fact card. Each player must lay down a card whether they are sure of their response or not.

After each player lays down a fact card, the dealer notes on a score sheet who won the round. There can be more than one winner for each turn and possibly there may be more than one winner for the game. The first person to lay down a fact card correctly wins that round and gains three points. At games end the total points are added up and the person with the largest score wins. To keep track of who was first, the first person to lay the correct card on top of the face card wins that round.

Components:
80 cards
- 40 face cards
- 40 fact cards

Name: World Citizen
Description:
The player will be able to identify the nationality of a person based on social interactions which include visual or written information about that person's country or culture.

Each player attempts to be the first to determine the nationality of the person described on the situation card and place a corresponding nationality card on the table. Each player must place a nationality card on the table OR forfeit one card to the discard pile. (Discarded cards remain out of play for the rest of the game). If two or more players place cards on the table simultaneously, then all cards for that play remain on the table and a second situation card is dealt over the first and players must attempt to match the second situation. Whomever wins the second play gets all of the cards on the table.

The GAME IS OVER when every situation card that can be correctly matched to a nationality card has been played. If a player runs out of nationality cards, she is out of the game until points are counted.

Components:
61 cards
- 25 Situation Cards
- 36 Nationality Cards

Name: Cocoa  A  Gogo
Description:
The object of the game is to earn the title of Cocoa-a-Gogo,the premier chocolate bean producer in the world.

There are two stages to the game. The first stage involves traveling around the outside track on the board collecting six cards ,resources needed to build your cacao plantation.  In the second stage, it takes 20 beans currency to buy the way in, and is played inside the inner board; reaching the center is the key to win the game.

Cocoa a gogo is a Kids roll'n move family game: negotiation is the key to get the items (resources).

Name: Zero Out
Description:
The learner will be able to recognize and combine algebraic-like terms into sets of three. Each set will "zero out" (have a net value of zero).

Players sort their cards by types of terms. They position cards of like terms together. Players take turns drawing the top card from the remaining deck or selecting the top card in the discard pile. During each turn, a player must draw from either pile and discard one card before their turn is over. Each player tries to make two sets of three cards. Each set must contain cards of like terms that "zero out."

The player who successfully goes out, gets a score of zero. The other players will add the absolute values of the coefficients of the terms in their hands to determine their score. The player with the lowest total at the end of a set number of rounds, is the winner.

Components:
86 cards

Name: Seii Taishogun: Sengoku Karuto
Description:
Seii Taishogun: Sengoku Karuto is the seventh title available in Small Box Games' Pure Card Line.

Sengoku Karuto loosely borrows from the theme and mechanics of one of Small Box Games' most popular games, Seii Taishogun.  Players are rival daimyo in Sengoku era Japan attempting to cleverly outwit eachother to gain control of various locations scattered across Japan's four main islands.

Unlike the original, each card represents one to three (1-3) samurai belonging to one of four clans and one of the following locations: temple, pagoda, or castle on one of the four islands of Japan.  Players secretly assemble armies comprised of Samurai from one of four clans to conquer new locations.  Armies constructed of Samurai from the same clan are more powerful than armies using various clans.  Additionally, players can persuade locations to rally under their banners or attempt to conquer another player's locations.

Players are awarded points at the end of the game for the locations they've conquered, with additional points being awarded when various conditions are met.

Name: Timber Tom: The Wollemi Pines
Description:
Bonus Expansion to the Timber Tom board game.

This mini expansion adds the rare and protected Wollemi Pine to the mountainsides of Timber Tom.  These special trees, once planted, cannot be removed!  As your hiking adventure progresses, you may happen upon a Wollemi Pine (strategically planted by a rival hiker).  Due to its protected status, you cannot remove this special tree from your path.  Find another route!

Also, be sure to expend your stash of precious Wollemi "seeds" while hiking, otherwise you will be penalized when you return to base camp.  Hikers are expected to help spread the rare Wollemis along the mountainsides.

Name: Schweinefrass
Description:
Schweinefrass is a card game, in which you have to remember, which cards were played before.
You play your food-cards face down on one of 7 pigs.
If a player pales a food-card on a pig, with the same kind of food already played on it, he has to return the card to his hand and must draw a new. 
The fisrt player with no cards left in his hand is the winner.

Name: Iskelmäkaraoke
Description:
From the publisher:
In this game, correct singing is not as important as convincing singing. The goal is to move on its own clubs, local karaoke cruises through every karaoke championship. On the way you present a well-known songs(finnish): "What to do with the special discs", "Sounds like the sea", "Do you know how sick" can you sing them or do you have the soap that is stuck in your throat? Other players are referees, and will have to present themselves convincingly if keep track of your performance sub-standard. The game has been carried out in collaboration with the popular songs in the radio. Words come with the game!
You win by getting right the all songs and by convincing the players about your singing abilties!

Name: Lexico Suomi-Saksa
Description: Lexico is a game and a dictionary combined in a unique and fun way. Beside its excellent game value, it also has a huge educational value and is of interest to anyone who wants to learn languages. Lexico features altogether 9000 commonly used words from five different categories: Human, Living environment, Nature and hobbies, Science and technology and Common words. The words are divided into 3 difficulty levels and the idea is that every player plays the difficulty level best suited for his/her language skills.

Name: Lexico Suomi-Venäjä
Description: Unique dictionary game is now completely renovated! Lexico contains a total of 9000 commonly used words, divided into five thematic areas: Human, Environment, Nature and Hobby, Science and Technology as well as the general words. Three different levels of difficulty thanks to the game is suitable for all ages and levels of language minds can play together - each of the chosen level of difficulty. Lexicon company you enjoy and learn a foreign language! Win by getting rid of all your cards first!

Name: Bungayopoly
Description:
Bungayopoly: the Bungay Business Game is a roll-and-move business game inheriting elements from Monopoly. It is a local interest game set in the town of Bungay, Suffolk, UK. The board is composed of 4 sections, each featuring a photograph of local a landmark and spaces representing local businesses.

Unlike Monopoly, the properties are preassigned, with each player owning all the properties on their segment of the board. Players may spend money to develop these properties to attract rent from players who land on them. The properties all generate the same rents. The game is player with a single 6-sided die. A single deck of 'Take a Street' event cards is used.

Name: Das Regenwaldspiel: ein WAS IST WAS – Wissensspiel
Description:
The rainforest is in danger - and you are in charge to save him. The gameboard shows the forest divided in square spaces. Basically players roll dice, move, answer questions and place a "save"-tile on their spot in case of a correct answer. Otherwise a die-roll decides wether that space will be destroyed.
Some expedition cards and rule details add minor tactical possibilities to the game. The first player who has saved 21 spaces wins.

Name: BANG! Wild West Show
Description:
No laws in the whole Wild West can stop them! They are strong, terrible, greedy, and they are mad!

New ruthless gunslingers run about the Wild West at breakneck speed, panicking the other gunmen. Their talent is madness, and so are the cards you’ll find in this crazy expansion! Your chances are hanging by a thread - can you measure up against unfair duels and unpredictable moves?

BANG! Wild West Show! is "a little double-faced expansion that contains eight VERY wild new characters, like one that draws cards from the other players hands instead of the deck, one with 9 life points who cannot use Missed! cards, [and] one that "draws" when it’s killed and stays alive if you do not draw Spades, ’cause you need a Spade to bury him!, [plus] a set of cards that come in play when you play a Wells Fargo and change the rules of the game until they are discarded... [and] craaaaazy cards, like the Wild West Show that lets you play Missed! cards as BANG!s and vice versa, [and] one that lets you swap your position with another player at the table..."

Name: Push
Description:
Push is played on a 8x8 square board.Each player starts with 16 stones 8 on each of the two back rows.
By moving the last stone in a row the player can push one or more stones as far as empty spaces are available,but not more than 3 cells.Push moves are either orthogonally or diagonally.
A player who fills the opposite two rows wins.

Name: Quad
Description:
Quad is played on an empty 8x8 square board.
There are 12 to 25 stones of each color off-board(the exact number should be decided by the players).
At each turn,each player must do one of the following things:
1.Drop a friendly stone into an empty cell.
2.Move a friendly stone to an orthogonally empty cell.
There are custodian captures(if the moving stone goes to a cell where an adjacent enemy stone is sided by it and another friendly stone,then the enemy stone is captured).
Wins the player that (a) makes an orthogonal 4 in-a-row,(b) stalemates the adversary or (c) captures all enemy stones.

Name: All About Town: Milwaukee
Description:
All About Town: Milwaukee is a unique board game with a map that takes you "all about town."  Travel along the freeway system, visiting familiar landmarks, and test your knowledge about Milwaukee County .  There are 1,500 brain-busting questions that challenge your Milwaukee County I.Q. Impress your family, friends, total strangers - and yourself - with all you know about people, business & industry, sports & entertainment, places ,and events - from the past to the present. What you don't know, you can learn - and have fun in the process!

Up to six teams/players can play All About Town: Milwaukee.  Start at   General  Mitchell  Airport  in your vintage mode of transportation and the race is on!  Travel around the game board answering questions about   Milwaukee  County  from six different categories.  Be the first to correctly answer questions corresponding to six landmarks and return to   Mitchell  Airport  – and you win!

Name: Uncle Chestnut's Card Gype
Description:
Almost 100 years after G.K. Chesterton and H.G. Wells created "the well-known and widespread national game of Gype" mentioned in Chesterton's Autobiography, Uncle Chestnut's Card Gype arrived on the scene.

Players use a 54 card deck to assemble items from Uncle Chestnut's pockets into topics for his lectures and books. The rules are simple, but ever-changing.

Card Gype features over 40 quotations from G.K. Chesterton, who was the basis for the fictional character "Uncle Chestnut."

This game is based on the Fluxx® game engine, designed by Andrew Looney, and is used with an understanding from Looney Labs®.

Name: Meeplecrawl
Description:
Meeplecrawl is a tactical dungeoncrawl where up to two parties of adventurers (each one consisting of a knight, a mage and three archers) delve into a dungeon in order to accomplish the goals of the job they got at the local tavern. Though a book with adventures will be released, players are encouraged to design their own adventures with the given dungeon elements.

Each meeple has a certain amount of action points each turn to move and fight. Combat is resolved with dicerolls.

Material needed additionally to the printable tiles:

    Meeples, Lots of them.
    5 green ones
    5 blue ones
    6 yellow ones
    24 black ones

Name: Supremacy at Sea
Description:
Originally entitled Actions Stations! (which was changed for copyright reasons), Supremacy at Sea - World War II Naval Combat is a the product of years of effort from a group of individuals known collectively as the University of British Columbia Sunday Night Crew.

Supremacy at Sea can be used for either quick scratch battles, or as part of larger campaigns. The rules are best suited to be used  with 1/2400 scale models, but can be used with anything from 1/1200 to 1/4800 scale.

Game contains rules for every aspect of naval combat including: ramming, laying smoke, searchlights, night-fighting, weather, radar, and more.

One interesting feature of the game is that players on the same side must talk strategy loudly enough for everyone at the table to hear. (This simulates the ability of both sides to intercept communications). However, orders are written down secretly and executed simultaneously.

Re-implemented by:

    SAS: Spee

Name: Peter Rabbit: A Game
Description: A Children's game from 1940.  It is based on the Peter Rabbit stories and is a very simple 2 player game.  The players spin a spinner and move accordingly with special events happening along the way.

Name: Little Boy Blue
Description:
A spinner based game from 1955 it has a bit more depth than the usual follow the path games.

Players guess where they think Little Boy Blue is hiding (which haystack) using their pegs to mark their guess.  Then you use their second token to race to their haystack (by spinning in turn and using the big number on the outside of the spinner). The first player to reach the end of their path gets a reward token and spins the spinner to see where Little Boy Blue is hiding (the inner number on the spinner).  Depending on the spin players take reward tokens or place them on haystacks to be won later.  Rounds are played until all reward tokens are gone.

Winner is the person with the most tokens.

Name: Lucky Fisherman Game
Description: Lucky Fisherman features four colors player colors, each with a pawn and 11 matching bait pieces. Each player spins a spinner and moves on the board. The color of the landing space indicates if you get to move your bait closer to a fish, move back, lose bait, spin again, etc. Once you get your bait far enough it goes in the net and you catch a fish.  There are 5 fish to catch at a time and 8 total for the game.  Your bait is limited, so if you lose too many bait pieces you are done.

Name: The Fisher Theatre Game
Description:
A roll-and-move local interest game themed around the Fisher Theatre in Bungay (Suffolk, UK).

Players roll a die to move around a board. If they land on an action space, they draw a card and then spend 10 seconds acting out the role described on the card. The remaining players vote on the act using counters. Depending on how the act is received, the player earns or loses audience tokens.

The first player to receive 21 audience tokens wins.

Name: Advanced Vive l'Empereur
Description:
Advanced Vive l'Empereur is a 2 players game that allows you to simulate, at a grand tactical level, the napoleonic great battles. Up to 6 infantry type, light, medium and heavy cavalry, medium, heavy and horse artillery are the units that as Commander in Chief you've got under your command. Just a few minutes to read the rules (only 4 pages), a new game system called "Histo Command dice", then, deploy the units and you'll be ready to relive and enjoy napoleonic tactics like: cavalry counter-charge, form squares and artillery opportunity fire.

Game contents:
1 map (cm 67x49,5) front/back printed
180 die-cut terrain hexagons (40mm each)
3 unit counters sheets
1 order cards sheet
8 special dice (5 black, 3 white)
1 die-cut labels sheet for dice
1d6
1d10
200 plastic chips in 3 colours
93 plastic stands
1 play rules
3 Historical scenarios: Waterloo, Ligny and Quatre Bras
1 Hypotetical battle scenario

Name: Grand Casino
Description:
From the publisher's website:

Grand Casino is a wonderful and exciting game for the whole family. It requires both skills and tactics, but a little bit of luck will also help.

The players are trying to form different patterns on the game board with their pyramids; your cards decide where you can place your pyramids. The player who forms the most patterns wins the game.

Name: Memories of Madras
Description:
Memories of Madras is a deck of 70 cards, each featuring a building in Madras. There are 7 suits of different colours with 10 cards in each, and a pair of Indian dice. Each card also has 1 or 2 keywords (e.g. Education). The rules suggest various games that can be played with the cards, such as Memory - collecting cards of the same suit; collecting sets of keywords; or trivia quizzes about Madras.

This game may be aimed more at the tourist / nostalgia market than at gamers.

Name: Drewdle
Description:
Drewdle is a Tile-Based Abstract Strategy & Hand Management game for 2 to 4 people. Players attempt to connect multiple Tiles together in certain positions to create the biggest chain/group of their selected Element.

Requirements


     The Drewdle Rulebook
     The 81 Drewdle Tiles
     The Drewdle Board
     Tokens for Tile Locking (Each Player needs a different colour)
             21 Red, Blue, Green & Yellow (a set for each player) and 6 Black (for Blocker Tiles, common to all players)
        
    
     2 to 4 Players (2 or 4 Players is recommended)


High Res Files and Rules available from Mediafire
http://www.mediafire.com/?sharekey=4efeb01be37e854407258ee67c679e4a2ad0b2f1ae5f1829284a1690ac06f797

Name: The Shell Game
Description:
The Shell Game is played with 4 or 5 cowrie shells, as is traditional in Indian games. The game comes with several sets of rules:

Version 1 - players throw 4 shells and score various points according to whether they fall dark side or light side up. For example, if all shells fall light side up, ten points are awarded to each player who grabs a shell.

Version 2 (Ramudu - Sita) - players throw 4 shells with each possible combination representing a character from the Ramayana. Players need to collect one of each result.

Version 3 - players place one shell (the striker) on the table and throw the other 4 onto it. Play then progresses through a complex series of challenges involving striking the other shells with the striker.

Name: Tryangles
Description:
Tryangles is a space-themed game having a board with a triangular grid containing a few black holes, planets, stars etc, with a Base area for each player. Each player has a set of triangle-based polyominoes containing 2, 3 or 4 spaces. A die is thrown to indicate whether a player may place a piece with 2, 3 or 4 spaces. Players place pieces over the special areas of the board with the constraints that:


     the player must first play in their base and all further plays must attach by at least two sides to pieces already on the board
     black holes may not be played on
     planets and stars must be fully occupied with one placement. Planets score 10 points and the sun scores 30 points.


The player to score the most points wins, though the rules do not specify a game end condition.

Name: Bomb Squad
Description:
In Bomb Squad, players take on the rolls of technicians, disarming an explosive device.  Just like the movies, there's a bunch of wires and you don't know which one to cut.

At the beginning of the game, one wire is removed from the deck and is the solution to the final puzzle.  During a turn, players play Stress cards on each other trying their nerves and each round the player with the least amount of stress gets to see the remaining Wire's dealt that round and has an opportunity to guess.  If no one guesses correctly after the third time through the deck, everyone loses as the bomb explodes.

Name: Elastro
Description:
Using an elastic band, each player tries to place his discs on the target (the closer to the center the better)
At the end of the game, a disc in the red central area is worth 10 points, 5 points in the blue one and 1 on the yellow circle.
A disc thrown out of the board is eliminated.

Name: Mine Out
Description:
Welcome to mining city. Any dream will come true once you rise to great fame in this city. Those who dream their fortune will proceed without any doubt even if they conduct illegal business. As we say, “Time is money”; time, money, resources, and laborers are all finite things. Don’t forget, everything has its limit. If your way of thinking is like “Next time I’ll try, but it’s OK now” it will prove to be a serious handicap in this city. Your resources will be mined out if you hesitate too long or are not vigilant enough.

Your mission is to acquire the most fame (points) by spending time (action points) in your own turn.  Hire laborers (cards) at the facilities on the game board and get their support for your mining business or benefit from their special expertise. Don’t hesitate to have the bank close down or a mine to be mined out in order to hamper the other players.

--from rules--

Name: Wehrmacht ‘47
Description:
This supplement for the WWII Micro Armour games adds various experimental projects such as the German E series vehicles. It expands the sequence of play to include ATGMs and also includes examples of painting models as well as weapons tables and 10 scenarios.

1 - Who Owns the Night?, May ‘47 
2 - Defense of Aleksino, May ‘47 
3 - The Empty Land, July ‘47 
4 - Grapple at Grachevka, September ‘47 
5 - Wadi El Ahmar, Fall ‘47 
6 - Welcome to Casablanca, Fall ‘47 
7 - Return to Hell, January ‘48 
8 - A Hell to Pay, June ‘48 
9 - Assault on Manduwan, Iran 
10 - Get a Piece of the Rock, September ‘48

Name: Ice Hockey
Description: This Milton Bradley Game comes with 1 wooden disc and two wire hockey "crooks". You play the game by first placing the disc on the center spot on the boards and then each player takes a wire crook and then trying to draw or knock the wooden disc (puck) through the goal to the players right. The opponent plays at the same time, each player trying to get the puck into their goal. The game is started by one player tapping 3 times and then calling 'GO!" The game is played to a predetermined number of gaols. The player reaching that pre-determined number wins.

Name: Trade the Market
Description:
Includes comes with  
22 Ticker Tape Cards 
26 News Cards 
Stack of Money 
Account Pad 
Insert Trays 
Playing Board 
Instructions
The Idea of the Game is to Trade Stocks...Buying, Selling, and Selling Short...so profitably that one becomes the richest trader and the Winner.

A player is chosen to "function" as the Stockbroker. The Market is Opened with the turning up of the top Ticker Tape and Unlimited trading, in Lots of 100 Share, may begin. Brokerage Commission is paid on every trade.

News Cards affect Stock Prices "UP" and "Down". A Record is kept of every trade and each change in price. Stocks may be bought on Margin (credit". A Market Closing Time is set, at which time all trading Stops.

Name: Champagne Adventure
Description:
Champagne Adventure  from 1989. An international board game of luxury and chance for 2 to 6 players. Object of the game: You can win Champagne Adventure in one of two ways. Either Acquire 10 million dollars in assets or  Collect and purchase one of each color Destination card.   The game comes with it's own  champagne glasses.

From the game box:  You have just purchased a London Townhouse at far below market value. The player to your left calls for an auction in Tokyo. Do you go or do you fly to Monte Carlo to make your fortune (or lose it) But wait,  the player to your right is throwing a party in Rio.  Etiquette requires all players to attend. What to do?  what to do??

Name: Shooting For The Moon
Description: This game is a shooting game from the 1920's or 1930's. The game consists of a wooden standup frame with two steel wire hooks that clamp into slots on the top and hold the two sided tin target. On the front side of the hook the two dart guns can be hung.  The game comes with 6 darts.

Name: Batalj
Description:
Batalj. This Swedish Alga game is essentially a newer version of the old Alga game Attack, which probably is related to L'Attaque. Therefore Batalj could be considered a "cousin" of Stratego. Designed by Count Sigvard Bernadotte, an uncle of H M King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden, and illustrated by Lars-Olof Jerhammar.

In the game you try to defeat your opponents army with your own. You only see the back of your opponents pieces so you don't know what piece is where. You try to use your stronger pieces to defeat your opponents weaker ones while protecting your weak ones. .

Differences between Stratego and Batalj:

-Batalj has 48 (2*24) pieces on a 64 square grid (8*8). Only the first 3 rows are filled in the initial setup.
-Instead of 'Bombs' Batalj has 'Cannon'. Cannons can only be defeated by the value 3 piece (Corporal).
-There are no 'Scouts' and the unit mix in general is slightly different.
-There are no 'lakes' nor any other obstructions on the board. 
-Striking is mandatory and happens immediately when a player moves a piece to a square directly in front (but not on the sides or back) of an opposing piece. A victorious striking piece does not occupy the opponent's space.
-There are no 'Flags'; winner is the first player to either eliminate or block all opposing pieces. In case of an impasse, the value of remaining pieces on both sides is counted and the higher total wins.
